data.title: Movies for Lawyers: 7 Legal Movies Every Indian Lawyer Should Watch
data.meta_description: In this article, we will discuss 7 legal movies that every Indian law student should watch. These movies are not only entertaining but also provide valuable insights into the legal profession.
data.text:
Movies have been an important part of our lives for many years. They entertain us, they make us laugh, they make us cry, and they even educate us. For law students, movies can be an excellent way to learn about the legal system and its various intricacies.

In this article, we will discuss 7 legal movies that every Indian law student should watch. These movies are not only entertaining but also provide valuable insights into the legal profession.

Watching legal movies can be a fun and engaging way for law students to learn more about the law, legal systems, and how they work. These movies for lawyers can help students in several ways:

Provides context and a practical understanding: Legal movies often provide a dramatized version of real-life legal situations, which can help students understand the practical application of the law in real life.

Helps students understand complex legal concepts: Movies can simplify complex legal concepts and explain them in a way that is more accessible and easy to understand.

Develops critical thinking skills: Legal movies often present complex ethical dilemmas and legal arguments, which can help law students develop their critical thinking skills and analyze different perspectives.

Inspires and motivates: Watching legal movies can also inspire and motivate law students, reminding them of the importance of the law and its role in upholding justice.

Court (2014)

Directed by Chaitanya Tamhane, Court is a critically acclaimed Indian movie that portrays the Indian judicial system in a very realistic and authentic manner. The movie follows the trial of an ageing folk singer who is accused of inciting a sewage worker to commit suicide. The movie highlights the flaws and complexities of the Indian judicial system and the struggles faced by the common man while dealing with it.

Pink (2016)

Directed by Aniruddha Roy Chowdhury, Pink is a Hindi movie that focuses on the issue of sexual harassment and consent. The movie revolves around three working women who are falsely accused of prostitution and attempt to murder. The movie portrays the challenges faced by women in India’s legal system and highlights the importance of consent and gender equality.

Shahid (2013)

Directed by Hansal Mehta, Shahid is a biographical drama that tells the story of Shahid Azmi, a lawyer and human rights activist who was assassinated in Mumbai in 2010. The movie depicts the struggles faced by Shahid while fighting for justice for his clients, many of whom were wrongly accused of terrorism. The movie highlights the importance of human rights and the courage required to fight against injustice.

Jolly LLB (2013)

Directed by Subhash Kapoor, Jolly LLB is a satirical comedy-drama that portrays the legal system in India in a humorous manner. The movie follows the journey of a struggling lawyer named Jolly, who takes up a high-profile hit-and-run case to prove his worth as a lawyer. The movie highlights the corruption and nepotism prevalent in the Indian legal system and the challenges faced by young lawyers.

Mulk (2018)

Directed by Anubhav Sinha, Mulk is a Hindi movie that deals with the issue of communalism and prejudice. The movie revolves around a Muslim family that is accused of aiding a terrorist attack. The movie portrays the difficulties faced by the family in proving their innocence and highlights the importance of religious harmony and secularism.

Court Martial (2020)

Directed by Sourabh Shrivastava, Court Martial is a Hindi movie that revolves around the trial of a soldier who is accused of killing five civilians in an encounter. The movie highlights the complexities of the military justice system and the moral dilemmas faced by soldiers while performing their duties. The movie also highlights the importance of upholding the values of justice and humanity in any situation.

Article 15 (2019)

Directed by Anubhav Sinha, Article 15 is a Hindi movie that deals with the issue of caste discrimination in India. The movie follows the investigation of a police officer into the disappearance of three Dalit girls. The movie highlights the deep-rooted caste prejudices prevalent in Indian society and the challenges faced by those who stand up against them.

Conclusion

Watching legal movies can be an excellent way for law students to gain valuable insights into the legal system and the complexities of the legal profession. The movies for lawyers listed above not only entertain but also educate and inform.

As lawyers, it is essential to understand the various aspects of the legal system and the challenges faced by those who work within it. These movies provide an excellent platform to do so. Overall, watching legal movies can be an effective way for law students to supplement their legal education and gain a better understanding of the law in action.
